Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Self-Assembled, H2S-Releasing Gels for Promoting Angiogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical summary
Despite its reputation as a foul-smelling, toxic gas, hydrogen sulfide gas (H2S) is a vital biological signaling molecule that is constantly produced and consumed in the human body. Over the past decade and a half, researchers have discovered that H2S carries out biological functions in the human brain, heart, liver, kidneys, and other organs. In all of these studies, however, none have examined the effects of H2S delivered from implantable materials. This CAREER award explores the synthesis and construction of the first-ever H2S-releasing gels and their effect on H2S signaling. Graduate students contributing to this project will use advanced techniques in organic chemistry, materials science, and cell biology to synthesize and fully characterize these novel materials. First-generation college students will be recruited to join the project as undergraduate researchers, exposing them to the field of biomaterials in a highly interdisciplinary laboratory environment. The gels that will be made over the course of this award will provide new tools for biologists studying the physiological roles of H2S, and results generated from this award will provide a basis for examining these materials as stimulators of angiogenesis, the process through which the body makes new blood vessels.

Technical Summary
Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is the most recently discovered addition to a critical class of gaseous biological signaling molecules called gasotransmitters. While the signaling capacity of H2S has been known for nearly two decades, no materials currently exist to deliver H2S in a controllable manner. As a result, how the signaling capacity of H2S is affected by localized (vs. systemic) release is unknown, as is the broader question of how matrix mechanical properties affect H2S signaling. This CAREER award focuses on the synthesis and characterization of novel peptide-based H2S-releasing gels and their effects on angiogenesis, the process through which the body makes new blood vessels from existing ones. The central hypothesis is that both the rate of H2S delivery and the mechanical properties of the matrix will influence pro-angiogenic H2S signaling. Graduate students involved in this project will use the tools of organic chemistry to develop the gels and characterize them using analytical techniques common in materials science, including electron microscopy, rheology, and other advanced analytical techniques. Through these efforts, the first family of H2S-releasing biomaterials will be designed, and these materials will provide a new understanding of how biochemical and biophysical cues can combine to promote angiogenesis.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This project focused on the development of new hydrogel materials capable of localized delivery of hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Despite its well-known toxicity and foul smell, H2S is a biological signaling gas that carries out vital signaling roles in nearly all types of mammalian cells. However, as this project began, no materials for H2S delivery existed. To address this gap, the investigators developed small molecules, termed H2S donors, designed to deliberately decompose in response to specific biological stimuli, such as water, thiols, or enzymes. These H2S donors were then attached to amphiphilic peptides that self-assembled in water into long nanostructures, many of which formed hydrogels upon addition of salts. In particular, S-aroylthiooximes (SATOs) were discovered to be a useful class of H2S donors that influenced both the type of nanostructure (e.g., cylinders, ribbons, coils) and, consequently, the rate of H2S release from the nanostructure or hydrogel. A variety of cell studies were conducted on the small molecule H2S donors as well as these peptide-based H2S-releasing materials. Taken together, these biological studies revealed that H2S delivery over the course of hours, whether from a small molecule, polymer, or hydrogel, was generally more effective in eliciting a desired biological response such as cell protection from oxidative stress than a burst release of H2S or very slow delivery over several days. These results have and will continue to impact the burgeoning field of H2S biology as scientists aim to uncover the various signaling roles of this gasotransmitter. This work will also impact chemists, biologists, and pharmacologists interested in H2S therapy, where controlled delivery is vital for achieving a desired therapeutic effect with minimal side effects. Key results from this work were disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals, oral and poster presentations by the PI and junior investigators at conferences, and seminars by the PI at colleges and universities around the world.

Broader Impacts: Undergraduate and graduate students at Virginia Tech contributed heavily to this project at the interface of organic chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, and biomaterials. In this effort, students learned state-of-the-art techniques in synthesis and characterization of organic compounds and peptides, nanoscale materials characterization techniques such as transmission electron microscopy, and cell culture and testing methods. Beyond campus, outreach efforts focused on the Virginia Tech Youth Experiencing Science (YES) program, a free, week-long summer camp for elementary-aged children in the local area focusing on exploration of materials. Graduate and undergraduate students associated with the project served as YES counselors, designing experiments and working with the campers to investigate various classes of natural and synthetic materials. During the pandemic in summer 2020, graduate students prepared science kits that were distributed to children in Montgomery country, Virginia.


Last Modified: 05/11/2021
Modified by: John B Matson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual merit: This project focused on the development of new hydrogel materials capable of localized delivery of hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Despite its well-known toxicity and foul smell, H2S is a biological signaling gas that carries out vital signaling roles in nearly all types of mammalian cells. However, as this project began, no materials for H2S delivery existed. To address this gap, the investigators developed small molecules, termed H2S donors, designed to deliberately decompose in response to specific biological stimuli, such as water, thiols, or enzymes. These H2S donors were then attached to amphiphilic peptides that self-assembled in water into long nanostructures, many of which formed hydrogels upon addition of salts. In particular, S-aroylthiooximes (SATOs) were discovered to be a useful class of H2S donors that influenced both the type of nanostructure (e.g., cylinders, ribbons, coils) and, consequently, the rate of H2S release from the nanostructure or hydrogel. A variety of cell studies were conducted on the small molecule H2S donors as well as these peptide-based H2S-releasing materials. Taken together, these biological studies revealed that H2S delivery over the course of hours, whether from a small molecule, polymer, or hydrogel, was generally more effective in eliciting a desired biological response such as cell protection from oxidative stress than a burst release of H2S or very slow delivery over several days. This work will also impact chemists, biologists, and pharmacologists interested in H2S therapy, where controlled delivery is vital for achieving a desired therapeutic effect with minimal side effects. Key results from this work were disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals, oral and poster presentations by the PI and junior investigators at conferences, and seminars by the PI at colleges and universities around the world. Broader Impacts: Undergraduate and graduate students at Virginia Tech contributed heavily to this project at the interface of organic chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, and biomaterials. Beyond campus, outreach efforts focused on the Virginia Tech Youth Experiencing Science (YES) program, a free, week-long summer camp for elementary-aged children in the local area focusing on exploration of materials. Graduate and undergraduate students associated with the project served as YES counselors, designing experiments and working with the campers to investigate various classes of natural and synthetic materials.
